context: Our monitoring systems have flagged several potentially malicious activities. Initially, Lucas Grey (Email: Lucas Grey@niseko.alpineskihouse.co) accessed a suspicious URL: `http://ym018491661.wittytree-b6f239d6.northeurope.azurecontainerapps.io/`. Following this event, there was an alert indicating the execution of a malicious PowerShell Cmdlet on a device. Further investigation revealed a potential DCSync attack initiated by Luciano Herrera (CIO) from MB-WINCLIENT, who sent a replication request to another machine. The final alert indicated that a key was accessed on that machine.
question: What is the name of the machine that accessed the DKM key of the ADFS object id 4cac49d3-29d3-407e-8c9b-b7ebb21541b2?
solution_steps: The user with AadUserId `a2d0f7c2-b0a0-43bd-bce0-27d8ae3be4d0` clicked on a potentially malicious URL.
A malicious PowerShell Cmdlet was invoked on the machine by the user with AadUserId `2de70991-2799-4a95-b734-8e3df3a50118`.
Luciano Herrera (CIO) on host `MB-WINCLIENT` sent 1 replication request to host `MB-DC1`, suspected to be a DCSync attack.
Host `MB-DC1` read the DKM key of the ADFS object with id `4cac49d3-29d3-407e-8c9b-b7ebb21541b2`.
